winterBark: Dark grey bark with shallow fissures in diamond pattern
winterBuds: Large red-brown buds, opposite arrangement, rounded with 5-7 bud scales
winterForm: Dense rounded crown, strong central leader when young
winterTwigs: Green twigs, milky sap when broken
summerLeaf: Bright green palmate leaves, 5-lobed with long pointed tips, milky sap from petiole when detached
summerFlower: Yellow-green flowers in upright clusters, appearing before leaves
summerFruit: Paired samaras with wings diverging at 180 degrees
juvenileFeatures: Smooth bark, vigorous growth, dense foliage
matureFeatures: Full rounded crown, shallow fissuring develops
veteranFeatures: Large spreading crown, some branch dieback
whyThisTree: Diagnostic milky sap distinguishes from all other maples. Common street tree with distinctive flat-winged seeds.
keyDifferentiators: ACER PSEUDOPLATANUS: No milky sap, grey bark more scaly, winged seeds V-shaped at acute angle not straight across. ACER CAMPESTRE: Much smaller leaves, corky bark on mature twigs, no milky sap. UNIQUE TO NORWAY MAPLE: Milky sap when leaf stalk or twig broken, samara wings at 180 degrees.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Distinctive red-brown buds with milky sap visible if broken. Summer: Full green foliage, milky sap diagnostic. Autumn: Clear yellow color.
identificationTips: Milky sap = Norway Maple (not Sycamore). Remember: platanoides = plane-like (leaf shape). Break a bud or leaf stalk to check for milky sap.

winterBark: Dark grey bark, shallow diamond-pattern fissures
winterBuds: Large red-brown buds, opposite arrangement, rounded
winterForm: Dense rounded crown, strong apical dominance when young
winterTwigs: Green twigs, milky sap when broken
summerLeaf: Dark purple-red palmate leaves, 5-lobed, milky sap from petiole
summerFlower: Yellow-green flowers before leaves, upright clusters
summerFruit: Paired samaras, wings at 180 degrees
matureFeatures: Full purple canopy, wider spreading form
whyThisTree: Purple-leaved cultivar of Norway Maple. Milky sap diagnostic for parent species. Popular ornamental street tree.
keyDifferentiators: ACER PLATANOIDES (parent): Green leaves, same form and buds. ACER PSEUDOPLATANUS ATROPURPUREUM: Purple underneath only, no milky sap, V-shaped seeds. PRUNUS CERASIFERA NIGRA: Purple leaves but cherry bark, no opposite buds. UNIQUE TO CRIMSON KING: Dark purple-red foliage throughout season plus milky sap confirms Norway Maple species.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Purple tinge in buds, red-brown color. Summer: Full purple foliage. Autumn: Purple persists, minimal color change.
identificationTips: Milky sap = Norway Maple species. Dark purple leaves = Crimson King cultivar. Purple color helps identify from distance, milky sap confirms species.

winterBark: Grey bark, scaling in irregular plates, pinkish-brown beneath
winterBuds: Large green-brown buds, opposite, pointed with scales edged in green
summerLeaf: Large palmate leaves, 5-lobed with rounded sinuses, dark green above, no milky sap
summerFlower: Yellow-green flowers in hanging racemes, after leaves emerge
summerFruit: Paired samaras, wings forming acute V-shape
matureFeatures: Flaking bark reveals pink-brown beneath
whyThisTree: Most common large tree in UK. No milky sap distinguishes from Norway Maple. Prolific self-seeder.
keyDifferentiators: ACER PLATANOIDES: Milky sap, red-brown buds, samara wings at 180 degrees not V-shaped. ACER CAMPESTRE: Much smaller with corky twigs on mature trees. UNIQUE TO SYCAMORE: Large leaves with no milky sap, samaras in V-shape, flaking grey-pink bark, flowers in hanging clusters after leaves.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Large green-brown buds, flaking bark. Summer: Hanging flower clusters after leaves. Autumn: Often brown, sometimes yellow.
identificationTips: No milky sap = Sycamore (not Norway Maple). Hanging flower clusters vs upright in Norway Maple. Pseudoplatanus = false plane.

winterBark: Grey-brown bark, developing corky ridges
winterBuds: Small reddish buds, opposite, hairy
winterTwigs: Developing corky wings on 2nd year growth
summerLeaf: Small palmate leaves, 5-lobed with rounded lobes, no milky sap
summerFlower: Small greenish flowers in upright clusters
summerFruit: Paired samaras, wings almost horizontal
matureFeatures: Corky bark develops on twigs and branches
whyThisTree: Only UK native maple. Distinctive corky bark on mature twigs diagnostic. Small leaves compared to other Acer.
keyDifferentiators: ACER PLATANOIDES: Much larger leaves, milky sap, no corky bark. ACER PSEUDOPLATANUS: Much larger leaves, no corky bark. CRATAEGUS (HAWTHORN): Similar small lobed leaves but alternate not opposite, thorny. UNIQUE TO FIELD MAPLE: Small maple with corky wings on mature twigs, only native Acer in UK.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Corky winged twigs distinctive, small buds. Summer: Small neat leaves. Autumn: Clear yellow to orange.
identificationTips: Look for corky wings on mature twigs - diagnostic for Field Maple. Smallest UK maple. Campestre = of the fields.

winterBark: Deeply fissured grey-brown bark forming vertical plates
winterBuds: Small brown buds in clusters at twig ends, alternate
winterForm: Broad spreading crown, strong central trunk
winterTwigs: Short irregular shoots, clustered buds at tips
summerLeaf: Lobed leaves with very short stalk (almost sessile), auricles at base
summerFlower: Inconspicuous catkins
summerFruit: Acorns on long stalks (2-7cm peduncle)
summerForm: Broad domed crown with massive framework
matureFeatures: Wide spreading crown, deeply fissured bark
whyThisTree: Most important native tree. Long-stalked acorns diagnostic vs Sessile Oak.
keyDifferentiators: QUERCUS PETRAEA (SESSILE OAK): Leaves have longer stalks, acorns sessile (no stalk), more upland distribution. QUERCUS CERRIS (TURKEY OAK): Whisker-like scales on buds and acorn cups, leaves more deeply cut. UNIQUE TO ENGLISH OAK: Acorns on long stalks, leaves with auricles at base and short stalks, lowland distribution.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Clustered buds at twig tips, deeply fissured bark. Summer: Short-stalked leaves. Autumn: Russet-brown, often persisting.
identificationTips: Acorn stalk length diagnostic: long stalk = English Oak, no stalk = Sessile Oak. Robur = strong/robust.

winterBark: Deeply fissured grey-brown bark, straighter fissures than English Oak
winterBuds: Small brown buds in clusters, alternate
winterForm: More upright crown than English Oak
summerLeaf: Lobed leaves with distinct stalk (1-2.5cm petiole), no auricles at base
summerFlower: Inconspicuous catkins
summerFruit: Acorns without stalks (sessile), sitting directly on twig
matureFeatures: More upright form, straight trunk
whyThisTree: Common in western uplands. Sessile acorns diagnostic. Straighter trunk than English Oak.
keyDifferentiators: QUERCUS ROBUR (ENGLISH OAK): Acorns on long stalks, leaves with auricles and short stalks, lowland distribution, more spreading crown. UNIQUE TO SESSILE OAK: Acorns without stalks (sessile), leaves with distinct petiole and no auricles, upright form, upland distribution.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Similar to English Oak but shoots straighter. Summer: Longer leaf stalks visible. Autumn: Russet-brown.
identificationTips: Acorn stalk: none = Sessile Oak. Leaf stalk: longer = Sessile Oak. Petraea = of rocky places (upland habitat).

winterBark: Pale grey bark, smooth when young, developing diamond-shaped fissures
winterBuds: Jet black buds, opposite, pointed, distinctive
winterForm: Tall straight trunk, airy crown when in leaf
summerLeaf: Pinnate compound leaves, 9-13 leaflets, serrated edges
summerFlower: Inconspicuous purple flowers before leaves
summerFruit: Clusters of single-winged keys (samaras) hanging in bunches
summerForm: Light open crown, often late to leaf
matureFeatures: Pale grey fissured bark, open crown
veteranFeatures: Often dying back due to ash dieback disease
whyThisTree: Distinctive jet black buds diagnostic in winter. Single-winged keys different from paired maple samaras. Threatened by ash dieback.
keyDifferentiators: FRAXINUS PENNSYLVANICA (RED ASH): Brown buds not black, smaller leaves. SORBUS AUCUPARIA (ROWAN): Similar pinnate leaves but alternate not opposite, red berries not keys, different bark. UNIQUE TO EUROPEAN ASH: Jet black opposite buds, pale grey bark, single-winged keys in hanging bunches.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Jet black buds unmistakable, smooth pale grey twigs. Summer: Last to leaf, first to drop. Autumn: Clear yellow if healthy.
identificationTips: Jet black opposite buds = Ash (nothing else has this). Keys hang in bunches. Excelsior = taller/higher (grows very tall).

winterBark: White bark with black diamond-shaped fissures, peeling in papery layers
winterBuds: Small brown buds, alternate, pointed, slightly sticky
winterTwigs: Long pendulous shoots, rough with warty texture
summerLeaf: Small triangular leaves, doubly serrate, long pointed tip
summerFlower: Catkins - male yellow pendulous, female green upright
summerFruit: Small winged nutlets in brown disintegrating catkins
matureFeatures: White bark with black diamonds, pendulous branches
veteranFeatures: Thick black fissures at base, heavy branching
whyThisTree: Weeping habit and warty shoots distinguish from Downy Birch. Triangular leaves with long point.
keyDifferentiators: BETULA PUBESCENS (DOWNY BIRCH): More upright habit, hairy shoots (not warty), leaves more rounded without long point, prefers wetter sites. UNIQUE TO SILVER BIRCH: Warty rough shoots, weeping habit, triangular leaves with long pointed tip, diamond-patterned white bark.
seasonalNotes: Winter: White bark visible, warty shoots, pendulous form. Summer: Light dancing foliage. Autumn: Clear gold.
identificationTips: Rough warty shoots = Silver Birch. Smooth hairy shoots = Downy Birch. Pendula = pendulous/weeping.

winterBark: White bark, less pronounced black fissuring than Silver Birch
winterBuds: Small brown buds, alternate, slightly hairy
winterForm: More upright form than Silver Birch
winterTwigs: Shoots with fine downy hairs, not warty
summerLeaf: Small oval leaves, doubly serrate, more rounded than Silver Birch
summerFlower: Catkins similar to Silver Birch
summerFruit: Small winged nutlets
matureFeatures: White bark, more upright than Silver Birch
veteranFeatures: Less black fissuring than Silver Birch
whyThisTree: Prefers wetter sites than Silver Birch. Upright habit and hairy shoots diagnostic.
keyDifferentiators: BETULA PENDULA (SILVER BIRCH): Warty shoots not hairy, weeping habit, triangular leaves with long point, drier sites. UNIQUE TO DOWNY BIRCH: Hairy shoots (not warty), more upright form, rounded leaves, prefers wetter habitats.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Smoother shoots with fine hairs. Summer: More rounded leaf form. Autumn: Gold.
identificationTips: Feel the shoots: hairy = Downy Birch, warty/rough = Silver Birch. Pubescens = downy/hairy.

winterBark: Smooth reddish-brown bark with horizontal lenticels, peeling in horizontal strips
winterBuds: Large reddish buds, alternate, clustered at shoot tips
summerLeaf: Oval leaves with serrated edges, pointed tip, dull green
summerFlower: White flowers in clusters, appearing with leaves
summerFruit: Small dark red to black cherries
matureFeatures: Bark starts to peel in strips, full crown
veteranFeatures: Large specimens with distinctive peeling bark
whyThisTree: Native cherry with distinctive peeling bark in horizontal bands. White flowers in clusters. Very bitter fruit.
keyDifferentiators: PRUNUS PADUS (BIRD CHERRY): White flowers in long spikes not clusters, black bark, different bark character. PRUNUS CERASIFERA (CHERRY PLUM): Much smaller, flowers before leaves, purple-black bark. UNIQUE TO WILD CHERRY: Reddish-brown bark peeling in horizontal strips with lenticels, white flowers in flat-topped clusters, bitter cherries.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Reddish bark with lenticels, large buds. Spring: White blossom with leaves. Autumn: Red tints.
identificationTips: Bark peels in horizontal bands (like masking tape). Avium = of the birds (they eat the cherries).

winterBark: Dark grey-brown to black bark, smooth with prominent lenticels, unpleasant smell when scratched
winterBuds: Small brown buds, alternate
winterTwigs: Twigs with unpleasant smell when broken
summerLeaf: Oval finely serrated leaves
summerFlower: White flowers in long drooping spikes (racemes)
summerFruit: Small black cherries in drooping spikes
matureFeatures: Black bark, dense crown
whyThisTree: Flowers in long drooping spikes distinguish from other cherries. Dark black bark. Unpleasant smell when scratched.
keyDifferentiators: PRUNUS AVIUM (WILD CHERRY): Reddish peeling bark, flowers in clusters not spikes. SORBUS AUCUPARIA (ROWAN): Pinnate leaves not simple, red berries, different bark. UNIQUE TO BIRD CHERRY: White flowers in long drooping racemes, smooth black bark with unpleasant smell when scratched, black cherries in spikes.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Black bark, scent when scratched. Spring: Long white flower spikes. Autumn: Yellow tints.
identificationTips: Long drooping flower spikes (like paintbrushes) diagnostic. Padus = ancient Greek name for wild cherry.

winterBark: Smooth silvery-grey bark, shiny with horizontal lenticels
winterBuds: Large purple-brown buds, alternate, with grey hairs
summerLeaf: Pinnate compound leaves, 11-15 leaflets, sharply serrate
summerFlower: Creamy-white flowers in dense flat-topped clusters
summerFruit: Bright orange-red berries in large clusters
matureFeatures: Full berry production, silvery bark
whyThisTree: Most common native Sorbus. Pinnate leaves with orange-red berries diagnostic. Silvery bark distinctive.
keyDifferentiators: SORBUS ARIA (WHITEBEAM): Simple not compound leaves, white underneath. SORBUS INTERMEDIA (SWEDISH WHITEBEAM): Partially lobed leaves, orange berries. FRAXINUS EXCELSIOR (ASH): Similar pinnate leaves but opposite not alternate, black buds, different bark. UNIQUE TO ROWAN: Pinnate leaves alternate on shoots, bright orange-red berries, smooth silvery-grey bark with lenticels.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Purple-brown hairy buds, silvery bark. Spring: Creamy blossom. Autumn: Orange berries, red-orange leaves.
identificationTips: Pinnate + alternate = Rowan. Pinnate + opposite = Ash. Aucuparia = bird-catcher (birds love the berries).

winterBark: Grey bark, smooth when young, becoming fissured
winterBuds: Green pointed buds with white hairs
summerLeaf: Simple oval leaves, white-downy underneath, green above
summerFlower: Creamy-white flowers in clusters
summerFruit: Orange-red ovoid berries
juvenileFeatures: Silvery appearance due to white leaf undersides
matureFeatures: Full crown, grey fissured bark
whyThisTree: Simple leaves white underneath diagnostic. Native to chalk and limestone. Common street tree.
keyDifferentiators: SORBUS AUCUPARIA (ROWAN): Pinnate compound leaves not simple. SORBUS INTERMEDIA (SWEDISH WHITEBEAM): Leaves lobed not simple oval. POPULUS ALBA (WHITE POPLAR): Leaves white underneath but lobed, alternate, different bark and habit. UNIQUE TO COMMON WHITEBEAM: Simple oval leaves with white-felted undersides, orange-red berries, grey bark, chalk/limestone specialist.
seasonalNotes: Winter: White hairy buds, grey bark. Spring: White blossom, silvery foliage effect. Autumn: Orange berries, silvery leaves.
identificationTips: Turn leaf over: white = Whitebeam. Silvery appearance of crown from distance. Aria = ancient name.

winterBark: Grey-brown bark with shallow fissures, often with masses of epicormic shoots at base
winterBuds: Small reddish buds, alternate, asymmetric
winterTwigs: Twigs often with aphid honeydew, developing aerial shoots
summerLeaf: Heart-shaped leaves, asymmetric base, serrate edge
summerFlower: Fragrant yellow-green flowers with leaf-like bract
summerFruit: Small hard nutlets attached to wing-like bract
matureFeatures: Massive trunk with epicormic growth, tall crown
whyThisTree: Hybrid between Small-leaved and Large-leaved Lime. Very common street tree. Masses of basal shoots and aphid honeydew problematic.
keyDifferentiators: TILIA CORDATA (SMALL-LEAVED LIME): Much less epicormic growth, smaller leaves, orange tufts in vein axils underneath. TILIA PLATYPHYLLOS (LARGE-LEAVED LIME): Larger leaves with white hairs, less epicormic growth. UNIQUE TO COMMON LIME: Masses of epicormic shoots from base and trunk, moderate-sized leaves, very common in streets and parks, hybrid origin.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Epicormic shoots masses at base. Summer: Heavy aphid drip, sticky leaves and ground. Autumn: Yellow.
identificationTips: Masses of shoots at trunk base = Common Lime. Sticky honeydew rain in summer under trees. Europaea = European (hybrid of two native species).

winterBark: Grey bark becoming fissured
winterBuds: Small reddish buds, alternate
summerLeaf: Small heart-shaped leaves (3-6cm), dark green, orange tufts in vein axils underneath
summerFlower: Fragrant cream-yellow flowers, later than other limes
summerFruit: Small thin-walled nutlets
matureFeatures: Minimal epicormic growth, neat form
whyThisTree: Native UK lime. Much neater than Common Lime. Orange tufts in leaf vein axils diagnostic.
keyDifferentiators: TILIA X EUROPAEA (COMMON LIME): Larger leaves, masses of epicormic shoots. TILIA PLATYPHYLLOS (LARGE-LEAVED LIME): Larger leaves with white hairs underneath, earlier flowering. UNIQUE TO SMALL-LEAVED LIME: Small leaves (3-6cm) with orange hair tufts in vein axils underneath, minimal epicormic growth, latest flowering lime.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Neat form, little epicormic growth. Summer: Orange tufts visible underneath leaves. Autumn: Yellow.
identificationTips: Turn leaf over: orange tufts in vein axils = Small-leaved Lime. Neatest lime. Cordata = heart-shaped.

winterBark: Smooth silver-grey bark remaining smooth even when old
winterBuds: Long pointed brown buds, alternate, distinctive cigar-shape
winterForm: Broad domed crown, branches often to ground level
summerLeaf: Oval leaves with wavy edges, silky hairs when young
summerFlower: Inconspicuous flowers
summerFruit: Prickly husks containing 2 triangular nuts (beech mast)
juvenileFeatures: Smooth grey bark, dense shade beneath
matureFeatures: Smooth elephant-grey bark, massive spreading crown
veteranFeatures: Huge trunks, smooth bark even when ancient
whyThisTree: Smooth grey bark diagnostic - remains smooth even in very old trees. Long cigar-shaped buds in winter.
keyDifferentiators: CARPINUS BETULUS (HORNBEAM): Similar leaves but doubly serrate not wavy-edged, fluted grey trunk not smooth, different buds and fruit. UNIQUE TO BEECH: Smooth silver-grey bark at all ages, long pointed cigar-shaped buds, wavy-edged leaves with silky hairs, prickly husked nuts, creates dense shade.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Long pointed buds, smooth grey bark. Summer: Dense shade, wavy leaves. Autumn: Copper-bronze, leaves often persist.
identificationTips: Smooth grey bark like elephant skin = Beech (not Hornbeam which is fluted). Sylvatica = of the woods.

winterBark: Smooth silver-grey bark
winterBuds: Long pointed brown buds with purple tinge
summerLeaf: Dark purple-red leaves, wavy edges, silky when young
summerFlower: Inconspicuous flowers
summerFruit: Prickly husks with nuts
summerForm: Majestic domed crown with purple foliage
matureFeatures: Full purple canopy
veteranFeatures: Purple tints remain in old specimens
whyThisTree: Purple-leaved cultivar of European Beech. Same smooth bark and cigar buds as parent species.
keyDifferentiators: FAGUS SYLVATICA (parent): Green leaves, otherwise identical. ACER PLATANOIDES CRIMSON KING: Purple leaves but opposite not alternate, milky sap, different bark and form. UNIQUE TO COPPER BEECH: Purple foliage with smooth grey bark and long pointed buds - combination diagnostic.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Purple tinge in buds, smooth grey bark. Summer: Full purple canopy. Autumn: Purple-bronze.
identificationTips: Purple + smooth grey bark + long buds = Copper Beech. Purpurea = purple.

winterBark: Smooth grey bark with distinctive vertical fluting creating muscular appearance
winterBuds: Small brown buds, alternate, pressed close to twig
winterForm: Rounded crown, often with multiple stems
summerLeaf: Oval leaves, doubly serrate, prominent parallel veins
summerFlower: Inconspicuous catkins
summerFruit: Clusters of three-lobed bracts with small nut
matureFeatures: Strongly fluted trunk, grey bark
whyThisTree: Fluted trunk diagnostic - looks like flexed muscles. Often confused with Beech but doubly serrate leaves and fluted bark distinguish it.
keyDifferentiators: FAGUS SYLVATICA (BEECH): Smooth bark not fluted, long pointed buds not small pressed buds, wavy-edged leaves not doubly serrate. UNIQUE TO HORNBEAM: Fluted muscular grey bark, doubly serrate leaves with prominent parallel veins, three-lobed winged fruits, small buds pressed to twig.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Fluted bark diagnostic, small pressed buds, old leaves persist. Summer: Doubly serrate leaves with parallel veins. Autumn: Yellow, leaves often persist.
identificationTips: Fluted muscular trunk = Hornbeam. Smooth trunk = Beech. Betulus = birch-like (similar leaves to birch).

winterBark: Distinctive patchwork of cream, grey, and brown where bark flakes off
winterBuds: Large brown buds, alternate, enclosed by leaf base
summerLeaf: Large palmate leaves (5-lobed), maple-like but alternate not opposite
summerFlower: Inconspicuous ball-like flower clusters
summerFruit: Distinctive spiky balls hanging on long stalks, 2-4 on each stalk
matureFeatures: Full bark patchwork, massive spreading limbs
whyThisTree: Most common London street tree. Patchwork bark diagnostic. Spiky ball fruits distinctive.
keyDifferentiators: ACER PSEUDOPLATANUS (SYCAMORE): Similar leaves but opposite not alternate, no bark flaking, different fruits. ACER PLATANOIDES (NORWAY MAPLE): Similar leaves but opposite, milky sap, no flaking bark. UNIQUE TO LONDON PLANE: Patchwork flaking bark cream/grey/brown, alternate palmate leaves, spiky ball fruits in groups on stalks, pollution tolerant.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Patchwork bark, spiky balls hanging. Summer: Large maple-like leaves (but alternate). Autumn: Yellow-brown.
identificationTips: Patchwork flaking bark = Plane. Leaves alternate not opposite (so not a maple). Ball fruits diagnostic. Hispanica = Spanish (hybrid origin).

winterBark: Reddish-orange bark in upper crown, grey-brown fissured at base
winterBuds: Pointed brown buds
winterForm: Conical when young, developing flat-topped irregular crown with age
summerLeaf: Paired needles (2 per fascicle), blue-green, twisted, 3-7cm long
summerFlower: Male cones yellow, female cones small and red
summerFruit: Small woody cones, egg-shaped
summerForm: Distinctive irregular crown with orange upper bark
matureFeatures: Orange-red bark in upper crown, irregular crown
whyThisTree: Only native UK pine. Orange bark in upper crown diagnostic. Paired twisted blue-green needles.
keyDifferentiators: PINUS NIGRA (AUSTRIAN PINE): Darker bark, longer darker needles (8-16cm), denser crown. LARIX DECIDUA (EUROPEAN LARCH): Deciduous needles in rosettes, different bark. UNIQUE TO SCOTS PINE: Reddish-orange bark in upper crown, paired blue-green twisted needles 3-7cm, irregular flat-topped crown in maturity, only native UK pine.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Orange bark visible, persistent needles. Summer: Blue-green foliage. Autumn: Evergreen.
identificationTips: Orange upper bark = Scots Pine. Two needles per bundle. Sylvestris = of the woods/forest.

winterBark: Dark grey-brown bark, fissured into small plates
winterBuds: Stalked purple-brown buds, alternate, blunt
winterTwigs: Purple-brown twigs, often with old cone-like fruits
summerLeaf: Rounded leaves with notched apex, doubly serrate, dark green
summerFlower: Small catkins, male reddish drooping, female small upright
summerFruit: Woody cone-like fruits persisting through winter
matureFeatures: Fissured dark bark, often by water
veteranFeatures: Large specimens often hollow, by water
whyThisTree: Wetland specialist - always near water. Woody cone-like fruits persist all year. Rounded leaves with notched tip.
keyDifferentiators: BETULA (BIRCH): Similar catkins but white bark, triangular leaves, different fruits. CORYLUS AVELLANA (HAZEL): Similar catkins but different bark, different leaves, true nuts not woody cones. UNIQUE TO COMMON ALDER: Rounded leaves with notched tip, woody cone-like fruits persisting, dark fissured bark, always in wet habitats, nitrogen-fixing.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Dark bark, woody cones and catkins visible. Summer: Dark green foliage by water. Autumn: Little color change, often green till leaf drop.
identificationTips: Woody cones through winter = Alder. Always near water (stream/pond specialist). Glutinosa = sticky (young leaves sticky).

winterBark: Grey-brown bark, fissured
winterBuds: Small brown buds, alternate
winterForm: Dense thorny rounded shrub or small tree
summerLeaf: Deeply lobed leaves, 3-7 lobes
summerFlower: White flowers (may blossom) in clusters, strong scent
summerFruit: Red haws (single-seeded berries)
matureFeatures: Full thorny crown, small stature
whyThisTree: Extremely common hedge and woodland edge plant. Thorns and deeply lobed leaves diagnostic. Strong-scented May blossom.
keyDifferentiators: CRATAEGUS LAEVIGATA (MIDLAND HAWTHORN): Shallower leaf lobes, 2-3 seeds per berry, ancient woodland indicator. PRUNUS SPINOSA (BLACKTHORN): Thorny but flowers before leaves, oval leaves not lobed, black sloes not red haws. UNIQUE TO HAWTHORN: Deeply lobed leaves, thorny shoots, white May blossom with distinctive scent, red haws with single seed.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Thorny shoots, red haws persist. Spring: White May blossom (strong scent). Autumn: Red haws, yellow-red leaves.
identificationTips: Thorns + deeply lobed leaves = Hawthorn. May blossom strong scent. Monogyna = one seed (in berry).

winterBark: Grey-brown bark, scaly
winterBuds: Small brown buds, may have spines on shoots
summerLeaf: Oval leaves, finely serrated
summerFlower: Pink-white blossom
summerFruit: Small yellow-green or red apples, very bitter
matureFeatures: Spreading crown, bark scaly
whyThisTree: Native wild apple. Small bitter fruit. May have thorns (unlike cultivated apples).
keyDifferentiators: MALUS DOMESTICA (CULTIVATED APPLE): Larger sweeter fruit, no thorns, more refined form. PRUNUS (CHERRIES): Similar blossom but different leaves, peeling bark, different fruit. PYRUS (PEAR): Similar but leaves more glossy, different fruit shape. UNIQUE TO CRAB APPLE: Small very bitter apples, may have thorny shoots, wild appearance, native species.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Thorny shoots may be present, scaly bark. Spring: Pink-white blossom. Autumn: Small bitter apples, yellow leaves.
identificationTips: Small bitter apples = Crab Apple (not cultivated). May have thorns. Sylvestris = of the woods (wild).

winterBark: Reddish-brown bark, flaking in thin plates
winterBuds: Small green buds
winterForm: Dense dark green crown, often broader than tall
summerLeaf: Dark green linear needles, arranged in two ranks, poisonous
summerFlower: Male cones small yellow, female green
summerFruit: Bright red fleshy aril surrounding poisonous seed
matureFeatures: Spreading form, can be massive girth
veteranFeatures: Can live thousands of years, massive hollow trunks
whyThisTree: Native evergreen. Extremely poisonous (except red aril). Can live for thousands of years. Dense dark foliage.
keyDifferentiators: TAXUS BACCATA FASTIGIATA (IRISH YEW): Narrow columnar form, needles radial not two-ranked. ABIES (FIR): Similar needles but with silver bands underneath, different cones, different bark. UNIQUE TO YEW: Dark green needles in two ranks, bright red arils, reddish flaking bark, extremely long-lived, highly poisonous foliage and seeds.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Evergreen dark foliage, reddish bark. Summer: Red arils ripen. Autumn: Evergreen.
identificationTips: Red berry-like arils = Yew (but seed inside poisonous). Dark evergreen in two ranks. Baccata = berry-bearing.

winterBark: Reddish-brown bark, flaking
winterBuds: Small green buds
summerLeaf: Dark green needles arranged radially around shoot (not two-ranked)
summerFlower: Male cones yellow, female green
summerFruit: Red fleshy arils
matureFeatures: Maintains narrow column
whyThisTree: Fastigiate cultivar of Common Yew. Narrow column form and radial needle arrangement diagnostic.
keyDifferentiators: TAXUS BACCATA (parent): Needles in two ranks not radial, spreading form not columnar. CUPRESSUS SEMPERVIRENS (ITALIAN CYPRESS): Similar column but scale leaves not needles, different cones and bark. UNIQUE TO IRISH YEW: Narrow columnar form with dark needles arranged radially around shoots, red arils, extremely poisonous.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Evergreen narrow column, dark foliage. Summer: Red arils on female trees. Autumn: Evergreen.
identificationTips: Narrow column + radial needles = Irish Yew. Still highly poisonous like parent. Fastigiata = upright/erect.

winterBark: Grey-brown bark with network of deep fissures
winterBuds: Small brown buds, alternate, pressed to twig
summerLeaf: Long narrow leaves, silvery-white hairs underneath giving silvery appearance to whole tree
summerFlower: Small catkins
summerFruit: Tiny capsules releasing fluffy seeds
summerForm: Tall with ascending branches creating silvery crown
matureFeatures: Fissured bark, tall ascending form
veteranFeatures: Large fissured trunk, often by water
whyThisTree: Common by rivers and streams. Silvery foliage from white leaf undersides. Grows very rapidly.
keyDifferentiators: SALIX FRAGILIS (CRACK WILLOW): Twigs snap cleanly at base (crack), leaves green both sides, more spreading crown. SALIX CAPREA (GOAT WILLOW): Broader leaves, different habitat (not strictly riparian), different form. POPULUS ALBA (WHITE POPLAR): Similar white leaf undersides but lobed leaves, fluted bark, suckers profusely. UNIQUE TO WHITE WILLOW: Long narrow leaves silvery underneath creating silver crown, ascending branches, crack willows crack but white willows don't snap cleanly, waterside habitat.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Olive or yellow twigs, fissured bark. Summer: Silvery crown effect. Autumn: Yellow.
identificationTips: Silvery crown from distance = White Willow. Long narrow leaves. Alba = white (silvery foliage).

winterBark: Smooth greenish-grey bark with diamond-shaped lenticels becoming fissured at base
winterBuds: Small reddish-brown buds, alternate, pointed
summerLeaf: Rounded leaves on flattened stalks causing leaves to tremble in slightest breeze
summerFlower: Catkins - male reddish, female green
summerFruit: Fluffy white seeds in early summer
matureFeatures: Full suckering, trembling foliage, fissured base
whyThisTree: Leaves flutter and rustle in slightest breeze due to flattened leaf stalks. Suckers profusely from roots.
keyDifferentiators: POPULUS ALBA (WHITE POPLAR): Lobed leaves white underneath, different bark, more substantial. POPULUS NIGRA (BLACK POPLAR): Larger triangular leaves, deeply fissured bark, different crown form. BETULA (BIRCH): Similar light crown but different leaves, white bark, no trembling. UNIQUE TO ASPEN: Rounded leaves on flattened stalks causing constant trembling movement, grey-green bark with diamonds, suckers extensively, distinctive rustling sound.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Grey bark with diamonds, extensive suckers. Summer: Trembling rustling foliage. Autumn: Clear gold.
identificationTips: Trembling rustling leaves = Aspen (flattened leaf stalks). Extensive suckering. Tremula = trembling.

winterBark: Grey-brown bark, deeply fissured and corky
winterBuds: Small brown buds, alternate, on short spurs
winterTwigs: Short spur shoots and long shoots
summerLeaf: Unique fan-shaped leaves with radiating veins, notched in middle
summerFlower: Male and female on different trees - small cones
summerFruit: Female trees produce smelly plum-like fruits
matureFeatures: Spreading form, distinctive foliage
whyThisTree: Living fossil - only surviving member of ancient group. Unique fan-shaped leaves unmistakable. Smelly fruits on female trees.
keyDifferentiators: NO SIMILAR SPECIES: Completely unique leaf shape - fan-shaped with radiating veins and central notch. Ancient lineage predating flowering plants. UNIQUE TO GINKGO: Fan-shaped leaves with radiating veins and notch, living fossil, smelly fruits on females, extremely pollution tolerant, brilliant gold autumn color.
seasonalNotes: Winter: Deciduous, bare, fissured bark. Summer: Unique fan-shaped foliage. Autumn: Spectacular pure gold color all at once.
identificationTips: Fan-shaped leaves = Ginkgo (nothing else like it). Living fossil. Female trees smell bad when fruiting. Biloba = two-lobed.
